column4: I have a computer with a 10 gig hard drive, and I want to know the most basic way to install a linux system on it, without taking all the disk space or anything like that, so I can also install games on it

it's my secondary computer that I mostly use for fun.  I was wondering if it's safe to JUST install Gnome, without installing other things, or if what I did originally installing Gentoo and then installing gnome on top of that was right
I'm really dumb about installing things, but I know how to use google =x
is it safe to just format my hard drive, and install gnome 2.10, or realistically what should I do?
also, how much space does gentoo and gnome combined take approximately?
well, my original question .. err one of the original ones, was if you need to have a system below gnome, or if you can just install gnome on a blank disk
is there any recommended system?
blimey!
naw, I see no need for alternative desktop environments.  I'm running gnome on the livecd package, and it seems really cool
granted asking this is like asking microsoft if there are better os's than windows in a way, but are there programs like gnome that are superior to gnome?
I guess quite a few people would argue for KDE for instance
Can't comment on that, I don't use KDE myself
i'm sure "kde vs gnome" gives lots of matches on google...
Well, you can try it yourself with the Kubuntu live-cd
do you want to format the entire hard drive or just a partition?
basically I want to start from scratch
and install ubuntu?
yeah, might as well.  I got sick of windows
well, in case you go for ubuntu, you can select "use entire hard disk" during install
that seems a lot easier than what I was doing earlier with gentoo
I guess it is :)

I want to eventually learn all about the general codes for using lilo/unix etc..  just as a hobby, but for the time being I have a friend chain laughing at me since I was at basically a dos'ish interface and couldn't access the internet for 2 days from the computer
Ubuntu probably provides a smoother transition to the linux world than gentoo
